fullProgramDescription: The Astrophysics major is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of the physical universe, from the properties of stars and galaxies to the behavior of matter and energy under extreme conditions. The program includes a strong foundation in physics and mathematics, as well as specialized courses in astrophysics.
shortProgramDescription: The Astrophysics B.S. provides a rigorous foundation in physics, mathematics, and astrophysics, preparing students for diverse careers or further study.
classHighlights: The Astrophysics major requires a strong foundation in physics, including Mechanics (PHYSICS 11A), Electricity and Magnetism (PHYSICS 11C), and Thermodynamics (PHYSICS 11D).
Students take core mathematics courses, including Calculus (MATH 31A, 31B) and Differential Equations (MATH 33B, PHYSICS 115B).
Astrophysics-specific courses cover topics such as Stellar Structure and Evolution, Galactic Astronomy, and Cosmology.
Students also complete laboratory courses, including Physics Laboratory (PHYSICS 4BL, 107L).
Electives allow students to explore topics such as planetary science, high-energy astrophysics, and computational methods.
learningOutcomes: Apply mathematical and physical principles to understand astrophysical phenomena.
Analyze and interpret data from astronomical observations and experiments.
Understand the principles of stellar structure, galaxy evolution, and cosmology.
Use computational methods to model and simulate astrophysical systems.
additionalInformation: Students must complete a set of preparation for the major courses, including physics and mathematics. Upper-division coursework includes astrophysics-specific classes and electives. GPA thresholds and other requirements apply.
